tweet: For 70 years, the federal government has promised to deal with nuclear waste – and yet all these decades later, we’ve made little progress. I’m not OK with leaving this serious environmental risk for our children to solve; we need to get serious about confronting this challenge. pic.twitter.com/BEIRBGnEfR

Our military alliance accomplished a great deal in destroying the caliphate, but ISIS is evolving into a global threat without a territory. We must deal with this new danger strategically and combat not only the fighters, but the ideology.

Appreciate @morningmika & @JoeNBC having me on @Morning_Joe to discuss the findings of my recent CODEL to Iraq – in particular, the ongoing threat that ISIS poses to security, both regionally and internationally. pic.twitter.com/AMx7cZjWKa

Through the efforts of the FOR/ME Initiative, the work of @UMaine researchers, and the ongoing dedication of forest industry leaders, this historic sector will continue to play a key role in rural Maine. https://www.newscentermaine.com/article/news/local/207/207-interview/from-paper-to-products-how-maines-forest-industry-is-adapting/97-ca39ebcf-b3fd-4179-8435-bb450d922623 …

Took this photo in Iraq last week: @SenDuckworth looking down as the helicopter taking us to Taji circled the spot where she was shot down 15 years ago while piloting her Blackhawk. This is a picture of courage, commitment and grit – I've got a new hero.  https://www.instagram.com/p/BwuOrddAKv4/  pic.twitter.com/pmbh1kwPGr
Sen. Lugar’s work with Senator Nunn on nuclear disarmament no doubt has made this world a safer place. His legacy is one for the ages.

It was with profound sadness that I learned today of the death of Senator Lugar, a giant of the Senate. Sen. Lugar was one of the very first senators I met with immediately after my election in 2012, and he was a model of bipartisan civility and accomplishment.

One of the highlights of this week in Iraq was the opportunity to spend time with these Airmen from the 243rd Engineering Installation Squadron of the Maine Air National Guard. I’m grateful for their service, and the work of all those working to around the globe to protect us. pic.twitter.com/oPcotxM9jp

After a whirlwind three days of meetings with American military officials, State Department officials, and Iraqi leaders, I’m returning to the Senate with a better understanding of our interests and the ongoing challenges in Iraq. Some initial impressions: pic.twitter.com/kICxnCxSKh

#EarthDay provides us all with the opportunity to come together to appreciate this planet we call home — and the opportunity to mobilize against climate change, the most pressing global challenge of our time. My thoughts on ways to respond to this crisis: https://medium.com/@SenatorKing/an-earth-day-reminder-no-time-to-waste-in-fight-against-climate-change-f017dd8792a5 …

But today cannot only be a day of rejoicing — we must also mourn those in Sri Lanka, who were senselessly attacked in their places of worship as they observed this sacred occasion. On this holy day, our hearts are with these victims and their families.
To those in Maine and around the world celebrating Easter and Passover, Mary and I wish you a happy holiday filled with joy and loved ones.

Appreciate the @bangordailynews giving deserved attention to the Earned Income Tax Credit — one of the most impactful policies we can use to help working families get and stay ahead. http://bangordailynews.com/2019/04/19/opinion/editorials/want-to-reduce-poverty-expand-the-earned-income-tax-credit/ …

Maine has a storied tradition of service to our country, and by breaking ground on this facility we are helping fulfill the commitment of a grateful state and nation to care for those who have served and sacrificed for us.

I will withhold my judgment on the Mueller report until I’ve been able to review the document – but the pointed political tone of today’s press conference did not match the transparent, objective approach needed to restore the American people's faith in our justice system.

From helping out at the local soup kitchen to supporting Maine seniors, volunteers are donating their time to improve the lives of others. The more people get involved, the more we can strengthen relationships, build understanding, and support those who need it most.

During National Volunteer Month, let us take time to honor those who are hard at work to improve their communities, and to reflect on what more each of us can do to get involved. Today in Lewiston, I visited with some of those folks who work to make Maine a better place. pic.twitter.com/nPOGy1t6gx

Pictured with Jennifer and Gabrielle is Helen Hall, who helped them navigate the complex system of the IRS and make things right. Helen works with Maine's only Low Income Taxpayer Clinic – today, I signed a letter urging additional funding for this program. pic.twitter.com/gk86bkmmBV

Also at today’s meeting were Jennifer Merrill and her daughter Gabrielle, who recently went through a multi-year process to correct an IRS error mistakenly claiming she owed $90,000. This time-consuming process upended their lives before it was resolved this month. pic.twitter.com/YrSD2SiaRE

On #TaxDay, we all want a tax system that is fairly enforced across the country. So today, I joined the good folks at @PineTreeLegal to push for changes to make sure the IRS doesn’t continue to target low-income Maine people. https://www.mainepublic.org/post/king-calls-tax-system-improvements-help-struggling-mainers …

The loss of this remarkable structure is the loss of a piece of our shared history; so saddened to see the impact of today’s fire. A special guest at last week's Capitol Coffee in my D.C. Office: Norm Brodeur, the man who gave me my motorcycle license test in 1995. And he came with gifts! I’ve told the story of my ride with Norm for nearly 25 years, so it was fun to reminisce about it with the man himself. pic.twitter.com/i6umfGIVvC

The EITC and CTC are two of the most effective tools in the existing tax code to help lower-income Americans and working families. In Maine, this bill could provide greater opportunities to 400,000 people, including 164,000 Maine children.

Maine families are feeling the effects of 2017’s misguided tax bill, and as tax day approaches I’ve cosponsored the Working Families Tax Relief Act to expand the Earned Income Tax Credit and Child Tax Credit.  https://www.king.senate.gov/newsroom/press-releases/king-backing-bill-to-cut-taxes-for-workers-and-families …

In Maine, there are certain basic principles of life: One is you don’t drive on the ice after April 15th, second is you hate the Yankees, and third is ‘if it ain’t broke don’t fix it’. That last rule is why I have questions about the proposed creation of a Space Force. pic.twitter.com/rUfZp2lX2p

The DRIVE-Safe Act addresses workforce shortages by creating an apprenticeship program to give a new generation of truckers training with a special emphasis on safety. In March's #InsideMaine, I spoke to Brian Parke of MMTA about this bill. Listen here: https://www.king.senate.gov/newsroom/inside-maine-podcast …

Covered a lot of ground with the folks at Maine Motor Transport Association (MMTA) last week! We discussed the biggest issue facing Maine’s trucking industry – a lack of qualified drivers – and the safe, commonsense solutions we’re working on here in Washington. pic.twitter.com/DfrPEYNmgU

From my time as governor, I know a key duty of the executive is to persuade legislators – not try to work around them. “The IRS is clearly wasting resources going after pennies in places like Washington and Piscataquis counties when there are dollars going uncollected elsewhere. Everyone should pay what they owe.” https://www.pressherald.com/2019/04/09/our-view-sen-king-is-right-irs-is-barking-up-the-wrong-tree/ …

The IRS audits residents of Washington and Piscataquis Counties – where the median income is roughly $40,000 – at a higher rate than wealthier counties across the country. That’s unacceptable. Today I urged the IRS to refocus their resources and stop targeting low-income Mainers. https://twitter.com/sunjournal/status/1115300778082799617 …
I'm always so impressed by Maine's Delegates to the Senate Youth Program: the engagement, intelligence, and curiosity of these students make me hopeful and excited for the next generation of leaders.

A pleasure to spend time with Jay Philbrick, a student at Maine School of Science and Mathematics in Limestone, and Joe Bergeon, a senior at Kennebunk High School, when they visited D.C. as Senate Youth Program Delegates. https://thecounty.me/2019/04/04/news/education/local-student-serves-in-senate-youth-program/ …

This long-overdue expansion is great news for the State of Maine. I will do everything I can in Washington to build on this work by defending the Affordable Care Act and fighting to maximize the Medicaid benefits Maine receives. #mepolitics

Life just got better for 70,000 Mainers. Medicaid is a lifeline for the most vulnerable members of our society, and now more Maine people in need will be able to access the high-quality healthcare they need to pursue happy, healthy, and productive lives. #mepolitics https://twitter.com/MainePublic/status/1113536177582280704 …

Rural Maine deserves a strong public health infrastructure just like other parts of our state. I am attacking this problem from all angles: I cosponsored the Equal Pay Act to address gender-based wage discrimination, the FAMILY Act and Strong Families Act to promote paid family leave, and introduced the PACE Act to promote affordable childcare. #EqualPayDay (2/2)

The wage gap’s impact on Maine communities is hurting families across our state: according to @NPWF, Maine women working full time make 18 cents less on the dollar than their male counterparts in the aggregate. It’s time to make this right. #EqualPayDay (1/2)

Our democracy is based on the public remaining informed. I had a great chat on @FiringLineShow about the tools available to Americans to maintain awareness and the age old question “Who will guard the guardians.” Thanks to @MargaretHoover for a great conversation! pic.twitter.com/lsnjCJYISp
